traffic officer"}]]}]]}]]}]]}],["$","section",null,{"className":"max-w-7xl mx-auto px-4 sm:px-6 lg:px-8 py-8 sm:py-12","children":["$","$L3",null,{"scenario":{"id":"traffic-stop","title":"Pulled Over by Police","icon":"ðŸš—","category":"Criminal / Police","description":"What to know when you're stopped by a traffic officer","rights":[{"title":"Right to Remain Silent","description":"You don't have to answer questions beyond providing your driver's license, vehicle registration, and proof of insurance. In stop-and-identify states, you must provide your name and ID, but you still don't have to answer other questions. Anything you say can be used against you in court.","source":"5th Amendment, Miranda Rights","stateVariations":[{"state":"UT","note":"Stop-and-identify state: must provide name and ID upon request"},{"state":"CA","note":"Can remain silent beyond ID; strong privacy protections apply"},{"state":"TX","note":"Stop-and-identify state: must provide ID if lawfully arrested"},{"state":"NY","note":"Can remain silent; provide name and address only if lawfully stopped"},{"state":"FL","note":"Stop-and-identify state: must provide ID"}]},{"title":"Right to Refuse a Vehicle Search","description":"Police cannot search your car without your consent, a warrant, or probable cause (like seeing drugs in plain view). You can clearly say 'I do not consent to a search' even if the officer insists. A dash cam recording of your refusal can protect you later.","source":"4th Amendment - Unreasonable Searches","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Strong protections against warrantless searches; plainly refuse consent"},{"state":"TX","note":"Can refuse search; officer may ask anyway but you can maintain refusal"},{"state":"NY","note":"Robust 4th Amendment protections; clearly refuse consent in writing if possible"}]},{"title":"Right to Record the Encounter","description":"You have the right to film or record police officers in public spaces while they're performing their duties. This is protected speech. However, don't obstruct the officer, get in their way, or interfere with their investigation.","source":"1st Amendment - Free Speech","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Explicitly permits recording police in public; strong protections"},{"state":"NY","note":"Recording police is protected; appellate courts have affirmed this right"},{"state":"TX","note":"Can record if you don't interfere; some ambiguity on audio recording"},{"state":"FL","note":"Can record in public, but two-party consent applies to audio in private spaces"}]},{"title":"Right to Know Why You Were Stopped","description":"Officers must tell you the reason for the stop. You can ask 'What am I being stopped for?' If the reason is unclear, note it and mention it to your attorney later. The stop must be based on reasonable suspicion of a traffic violation or crime.","source":"4th Amendment - Terry Stop Doctrine","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to an Attorney","description":"If you are arrested, you have the right to request a lawyer before answering any questions. Say clearly: 'I want to speak to an attorney.' Once you request a lawyer, police must stop questioning you. Do not answer questions after this request.","source":"6th Amendment - Right to Counsel, Miranda Rights","stateVariations":[]}]},"availableStates":["CA","FL","NY","TX","UT"]}]}],"$L4"]}],null,"$L5"]}],"loading":null,"isPartial":false}
